To Whom It May Concern:

We are writing to you and your department both as US citizens and parents-to-be
of a child from China regarding current USCIS regulations that affect the process
and cost of China adoption. This letter contains a little bit about us and a proposal
for changing the current system. Our dream of completing a family has been a
journey. We have a son we adopted from Korea in 2004 and now we are waiting
for our daughter from China. The process for both has been quite involved with our
Chinese adoption process currently taking almost double the time that we had to
wait for our son three years ago. We have had to submit to the scrutiny of our
adoption agency, our state, our federal government, and the Chinese government.
The investment of our time, money and emotions has been substantial. We have
followed all the rules of both the United States and the Peoples Republic of China.
We filled out the dozens of required forms, ordered the required documents,
prepared our dossier and immigration files and sent them to China. And now the
long wait for our daughter truly begins. As part of this process we are required to
obtain USCIS approval (form I-171H/I-797C). According to current regulations, this
document is valid for 18 months. Until recently, this approval period served
families in the process of China adoption quite well. They were able to receive
their child referral, travel to China, receive their child and submit an I-600 in
Guangzhou for their child?s visa. This is what we had been looking forward to for
our family, our adoption journey. Unfortunately, China is now experiencing a
significant increase in the length of time it will take to match us with our child.
This increased waiting timeline has occurred quickly and with dramatic effects. It
is a certainty that every family who has a dossier in China will experience the
expiration of their: 1) fingerprints (valid for 15 months) and I-171H/I-797C approval
(valid for 18 months). The cost, both emotionally and financially of filing a new I-
600A will be very high. The cost to your USCIS offices for processing a new I-
600A will be very costly and time consuming. We would like to propose the
following:
1) Effective immediately, set the validity period for all newly issued I-171H/I-797C
from 18 to 24 months.
2) Effective immediately, allow all families holding a valid I-171H/I-797C to file and
be approved for an extension to 24 months within 30 days after submitting the
following documents:
a. A copy of their current I-171H/I-797C and valid fingerprints
b. A Home Study update to ensure that families still qualify to adopt from China.

With the proposed increased USCIS fees as well as the longer wait times for
adoption from China, the current cost for fingerprints and I-600A will increase from
$685 to $1660. Please help us with relief of the burden to submit another I-600A
for a new I-171H when we have not even had the chance to use the one you gave
us initially. Please do not add additional time and cost simply because we want to
be parents! We implore you to look at the need and rational behind a completely
new file when these timelines are now here through no fault of our own.

Thank you for your time and thoughtfulness about this matter.

Sincerely,

Diane Hazlett
Painted Post, NY
attributes.title: Comment Submitted by Adoptive Parent, Diane
